payload.name: systems-thinking
payload.core: Reason about interacting components whose behavior over time cannot be predicted from parts alone. Core primitives: reinforcing loops (R), balancing loops (B), delays, stocks (accumulations), flows (rates), and emergence from loop dominance shifts.
proc: Define problem dynamically: state undesired behavior pattern over time (growth, oscillation, collapse, stagnation)
Draw reference mode: sketch expected trajectory vs actual trajectory on time axis
Identify 5-15 key variables; classify each as stock (accumulates) or auxiliary (computed)
For each stock, name at least one inflow and one outflow with units
Draw influence arrows with +/- signs; + means same direction, - means opposite
Trace loops back to origin; count sign flips: even = R (reinforcing), odd = B (balancing)
Label each loop with descriptive name capturing its behavioral role
Insert delays where effect lags cause by > 1 time unit; note order of magnitude
Identify boundary: list exogenous variables and justify exclusion of others
Locate leverage points using Meadows hierarchy: paradigm > goals > structure > feedback > parameters
Write dynamic hypothesis: [problem pattern] occurs because [loop name] dominates when [condition], leading to [consequence]
Derive testable prediction: if [intervention], then [measurable outcome] by [timeframe]
Validate: compare prediction to historical data, simulation, or natural experiment
quick_check: Can you point to at least one stock with explicit units?
Is every loop closed (path returns to starting variable)?
Is at least one delay quantified with order-of-magnitude estimate?
Does dynamic hypothesis name a specific loop and condition?
Is prediction falsifiable with named metric and timeframe?
check: Every loop labeled R/B with descriptive name reflecting behavioral role
At least one stock with inflow/outflow pair, all with consistent units
Delays marked where lag > 1 time unit; magnitude estimated
Boundary explicit: exogenous vars identified and inclusion criteria stated
Dynamic hypothesis specifies loop, condition for dominance, and observable consequence
Reference mode drawn showing expected vs actual behavior over time
Leverage points ranked; at least one structural intervention identified

mechanistic.contrast: Mechanistic = how component works inside; Systems = how components interact over time for emergent patterns
mechanistic.boundary: Use mechanistic first to understand each component, then systems to understand their interaction
mechanistic.test: If problem is 'why does X fail?' use mechanistic. If problem is 'why does behavior persist despite intervention?' use systems

model-based-simulation.contrast: Simulation runs quantitative models forward in time; Systems builds qualitative structure (loops, delays) first
model-based-simulation.boundary: Systems provides the causal structure; simulation tests parameter sensitivity and timing
model-based-simulation.test: If you lack loop structure, systems first. If you have structure and need trajectories, simulate

qualitative.contrast: Qualitative = directional sign propagation through chains; Systems adds loop closure, delay analysis, and stock-flow distinction
qualitative.boundary: Use qualitative for quick impact tracing; escalate to systems when oscillation or counterintuitive behavior appears
qualitative.test: If behavior is monotonic and predictable, qualitative suffices. If behavior oscillates or reverses, use systems

counterfactual.contrast: Counterfactual asks 'what if X had been different?'; Systems asks 'what structure causes this behavior pattern?'
counterfactual.boundary: Systems provides the model; counterfactual queries alternate parameter settings on that model
counterfactual.test: If explaining past event, counterfactual. If explaining recurring pattern, systems

causal-inference.contrast: Causal inference estimates effect size of intervention; Systems maps feedback structure that may nullify or amplify intervention
causal-inference.boundary: Causal inference assumes stable structure; systems reveals when structure changes or feedback undermines intervention
causal-inference.test: If system is at equilibrium and you need effect size, causal inference. If system is dynamic with feedback, systems first

confusions.symptom: Drawing influence diagrams without closing loops or distinguishing stocks from flows
confusions.resolution: Qualitative is open-chain sign propagation. Systems requires: (1) closed loops, (2) explicit stocks, (3) delay analysis. If your diagram has no loops, you are doing qualitative, not systems thinking.

confusions.symptom: Explaining how each component works but missing emergent behavior from interactions
confusions.resolution: Mechanistic decomposes into parts and explains each. Systems asks: what happens when these parts interact over time? Look for: feedback, delays, accumulation. If parts operate independently, mechanistic suffices.

confusions.symptom: Jumping to simulation without articulating loop structure or testing qualitative predictions first
confusions.resolution: Simulation is quantitative execution. Systems is qualitative structure. Correct sequence: systems thinking produces CLD and dynamic hypothesis, simulation tests sensitivity. Skipping systems makes simulation a black box.

fail.mode: Vague loop stories without measurable hypotheses
fail.signal: Cannot name stocks with units, cannot specify which loop dominates under what condition, cannot state falsifiable prediction with metric and timeframe

mit.name: Stock discipline
mit.rule: Every stock must have name, unit, and at least one inflow and outflow identified
mit.test: Can you write: 'Stock [X] measured in [units] increases via [inflow] and decreases via [outflow]'?
mit.example: Stock 'technical debt' measured in 'hours-to-fix' increases via 'shortcuts taken' and decreases via 'refactoring effort'

mit.name: Loop dominance specificity
mit.rule: Dynamic hypothesis must name which loop dominates under which measurable condition
mit.test: Can you write: 'Loop [R/B name] dominates when [variable] exceeds [threshold]'?
mit.example: Loop R1-Burnout-Spiral dominates when on-call-load exceeds 10 pages/person/week

mit.name: Delay quantification
mit.rule: Every marked delay must have order-of-magnitude estimate with basis
mit.test: Can you write: 'Delay of [N] [time-units] based on [evidence]'?
mit.example: Delay of 3 months based on historical new-hire ramp-up data

mit.name: Falsifiable prediction
mit.rule: Prediction must specify intervention, metric, direction, and timeframe
mit.test: Can you write: 'If [intervention], then [metric] will [direction] by [amount] within [timeframe]'?
mit.example: If we reduce ramp-up to 1 month, attrition rate will drop by 30% within 6 months

mit.name: Boundary justification
mit.rule: Exogenous variables must be listed with reason for exclusion from feedback
mit.test: Can you write: 'Variable [X] is exogenous because [reason it does not respond to system variables]'?
mit.example: Market salary rate is exogenous because our hiring volume does not affect regional tech salaries

use: Org design: hiring velocity, onboarding capacity, incentive structures, knowledge transfer
Markets: supply/demand dynamics, network effects, platform ecosystems, adoption curves
Reliability engineering: alert fatigue, incident cascades, capacity planning, on-call sustainability
Long-term planning: policy resistance, unintended consequences, goal erosion, shifting-the-burden
Technical debt: quality-speed tradeoffs, defect accumulation, refactoring thresholds

rel.name: mechanistic
rel.note: use before systems to understand how each component works

rel.name: model-based-simulation
rel.note: use after systems to run quantitative scenarios on loop structure

rel.name: qualitative
rel.note: simpler mode for open-chain reasoning without loop closure

rel.name: counterfactual
rel.note: queries alternate histories using systems model as substrate

rel.name: causal-inference
rel.note: estimates effect sizes; systems reveals when feedback undermines estimates

micro_ex.problem: Why does code quality degrade despite code review mandates?

loops.R1: Debt-Burden: debt -> slow delivery -> pressure -> shortcuts -> more debt
loops.B1: Review-Gate: shortcuts -> review rejection -> forced fixes -> less debt

micro_ex.delay: Review feedback delay ~2 days; debt visibility delay ~1 sprint
micro_ex.hypothesis: R1 dominates when review backlog > 3 days, causing shortcuts to bypass stale reviews
micro_ex.prediction: Reducing review latency to < 1 day shifts dominance to B1, reducing debt accumulation by 40% in 2 sprints

ex.problem: Why does on-call team burn out despite hiring?
ex.reference_mode: Expected: load/person stable after hiring surge. Actual: load/person spikes 2-3 months post-hire, then attrition wave

loops.name: R1
loops.label: Burnout spiral
loops.path: high load -> burnout -> attrition -> fewer people -> higher load

loops.name: B1
loops.label: Hiring response
loops.path: high load -> visible pain -> hiring approved -> new hires -> lower load

boundary.justification: Our team size does not affect market rates; user base grows independently of ops staffing

ex.hypothesis: R1 dominates when ramp-up delay > 2 months, causing attrition to outpace net capacity gain from hiring
ex.prediction: If ramp-up cut to 1 month via improved onboarding, attrition rate drops by 30% within 6 months

leverage_points.intervention: Pair new hires with dedicated mentor (reduces ramp-up delay)
Make burnout visible earlier via weekly load dashboards
Increase hiring budget (weakest leverage; does not change delay structure)
